summary: This is an email exchange between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell trial. It involves the sharing of a legal brief and a judicial opinion concerning the admissibility of mental health evidence, specifically related to an expert named Sasso. The correspondence highlights procedural issues with redacting and sealing documents.

persons.name: Sasso
persons.context: Mentioned as the subject of a legal brief regarding the admissibility of mental health evidence in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Author of an opinion that is attached to the email, indicating judicial oversight of the Maxwell case proceedings.

connections.description: Judge Nathan issued an opinion related to the admissibility of evidence from expert Sasso in the Maxwell trial.

events.title: Filing of Motion and Order regarding Sasso evidence
events.description: A motion and a temporary sealing memorandum, opinion, and order were filed concerning the admissibility of mental health evidence from expert Sasso in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

events.title: Email exchange regarding Maxwell briefing
events.description: Prosecutors exchanged emails sharing a legal brief and a judicial opinion related to the admissibility of expert mental health testimony in the Maxwell case.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel dated November 24, 2021.
It discusses a legal brief filed regarding the admissibility of mental health evidence from an expert named Sasso in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.
An opinion by U.S. District Judge Nathan on this matter is attached to the email.
The correspondence mentions that the prosecution had litigated about nine experts at that point in the case.
It notes procedural complications with redacting and sealing documents in the case.
